>>52823979
Sadly no.
Wait until you have 6 Pokemon that require the same stat, give them all the power item, level up one of them with candies so it can OHKO the Pokemon easily, and then KO a bunch.

You can do mixed batches by giving them the other power item and then switching to the power item of whatever you're KOing when that maxes out.

e.g. training 3 physical attackers and 3 special attackers, all with 252/252 speed spreads
Give 3 phys attackers power bracer and 3 special attackers power lens, go to town on a wingull swam. Once their attacking stat is maxed out (32 battles), switch all their items to power anklet and do another 25.

>>52824031
Espathra: Fairy if Speed Boost/CM/Stored Power/Dazzling Gleam (most common set)
Brute Bonnet: any defensive type that covers its weaknesses Water, Fairy or Steel
Lokix: can be left as Bug for big First Impressions
Skeledirge: probably can be left as Fire
Garganacl: Ghost, or Grass if worried about Meowscarada
Iron Valiant: frail with good coverage, can be left as Fighting or Fairy

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My favourite explanation for the whole thing: most pokemon naturally want to fight and become stronger, so when they are beaten or sufficiently impressed by trainer or his pokemon, they willingly accept capture in order to train under them and become better. Kinda like shonen antagonists who join protag's party after getting their asses beat by them. The whole system runs on pokemon recognizing and honouring trainer's strength, which is also why traded high level pokemon will not listen to you - you've yet to prove your worth to them, and only by beating 8 gym leaders and presenting their badges you can earn their respect. That interpretation dodges the whole "enslavement" thing and gives pokemon agency and intelligence, the only caveat being that majority of pokemon are naturally hardwired to fight and intent to grow stronger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52821580
Nah, it's even worse than that. They have the rights.

https://forums.bulbagarden.net/index.php?threads/an-explanation-for-why-japanese-tracks-are-replaced-in-the-dub.281406/#:~:text=Thus%2C%20rather%20than%20allowing%20the,languages%3B%20their%20dubbed%20music%20still

>Basically, it's all because 4Kids (at the time) had the brilliant idea to have residuals on their localized work, to make more money. People that license the music for shows earn residuals from when & where they're played. Thus, rather than allowing the original music licensees to have that, 4Kids (and later TCPi) decided to fill localized episodes with their own music-that way, they could still make money even if Pokemon aired in other parts of the world with different voice actors speaking other languages; their dubbed music still plays, and thus they still make money.

>From a business standpoint, I have to admit I don't see the flaw in their plan. It's a smart way to make even more money. It also explains why Yu-Gi-Oh (who Stuart also worked on) and Digimon also changed a majority, if not all, of their musical scores too; it's a practice they kept, I guess.

>However, you have anime like Bleach, One Piece, Hunter x Hunter, Naruto, etc. whose music wasn't changed for the sake of money. I greatly appreciate this as I've come to love a lot music from these series. It's a shame because there's such amazing music and renditions that dub watchers wouldn't ordinarily get to hear, due to this practice. This also confirms for me that TCPi is fully capable of keeping every track within an episode; they just choose not to. However, there's probably an agreement where a percentage of tracks are kept-which is what we sparsely hear.

https://youtu.be/nKL6W8ctQ5w

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52813974
Works sometimes, getting rid of secondary typings to become say, mono-water with a stat boost is good.
The real issue with Infinite Fusion is two fold. First a smaller one that most fusions have one orientation that is objectively better than the other, which on its own isn't an issue, but can become one because oftentimes you'll have one with great pixel art, and another with an computer generated sprite, and the computer generated fusion sprite represents better stats and abilities/typing. So the effort put in becomes wasted.
Second that the equations they use to calculate the stats end up averaging down the Base Stats of both monsters most of the time. Its only really ever 'worth it' to Fuse two monsters of the same rough BST total, that have opposite Stat distributions. This is larger and more fundamental to the system. In a game where the gimmick is fusing, its very situational whether its going to be at all worth it.
posts.filename: Left Has Hand Drawn Sprite But Bad Stats

You would appreciate some aspects of Prism more if you played Brown first.
Brown, the protagonist is a superboss in Prism. Mura, the rival of Brown, is an Elite 4 member in Prism too. The Palette Ranger leader was a superboss in Brown originally and said what his plan for Prism was. Prism also has some interesting lore like Brown actually losing the championship fight to Lance. The Rijon portion of Prism has some references to Brown too.
Brown is an alright game. It's gen 1 mechanics but it has post gen 1 pokemon like Electivire and it's interesting to see how they work with the Special stat. Gym fights are fun. The protagonist also isn't silent.

>>52824376
It's not just the PP nerf.
Cutting access to Scald means physical attackers don't have to fear switching in on bulky waters.
Cutting access to Knock Off means choice users don't have to fear switching in on other fatmons.
Cutting access to Toxic means that a lot of fatmons have no way of even dealing damage.
Glimmora means it's easier than ever to get hazards up, and this is before H-Samurott and Kleavor come back.
Gholdengo means it's harder than ever to get rid of hazards.
Not even taking into account the simple fact that offense has gotten way more toys than defense has.

The pure "do nothing" stall that gen 8 was infested with is well and truly dead. There's no bringing it back.

I'm curious how many people think about the OP posts as writing prompts. Plenty of the titles, either of the image or the thread, actually point in the general direction of a less-than-obvious interpretation of the picture.

Like how this one is pointing out how Torii gates are meant to represent "crossing" from the mundane to the sacred, often with implied purification. This being from a Japanese Pixiv account, it's almost certainly more than just a literal portal, hence using "Grudges Settled" to denote interpreting it as passing on, either in the "finally gets to die" sense or just calming the fuck down.

That's going to be a challenge. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Game takes place on abandoned island, old labs are everywhere, most enemies on the island are fossil & past Paradox pokemon
Galarian Slowking - big bad of the 5 major antagonists, wanders the island periodically, has 2 Mightyena that patrol with him, should either of them spot you the skybox becomes the interior of the move trick room, and he chases you faster than he normally would
Mega Gyarados - monster in the lake, you must swim in said lake to access more of the island
Dusknoir - resides in all larger labs, acting as a grave keeper to the mons that perished in them, only appears as a shadow on the floor, flashlights are your key to evading his grip
Fossil/Paradox Pokemon - many scattered throughout the island, most are more pest-like and can't one hit kill you, except Tyrantrum, Dracovish, & Roaring Moon
Rayquaza - caused your plane to crash, only appears during heavy storms caused by one of the deep labs, should you not be in a lab while it surveys the island it will kill you, only benefit from this is that it scares all other pokemon away, except the lab dwelling ones
Oh and if you try to swim away from the island a Wailord kills you

I'm his fan since day one and desu it's not that surprising. I thought people were mostly joking when they play along with my horny Gholdengo posts (now I know that's probably not the case)

Goldbro shares very little features with the actually popular mons. He's goofy and kinda cute but not in the "Awwww what a cute little creature!" way. He's super humanoid but he's not straight up cool like the megamans and he's certainly not a waifumon. He doesn't have a single animalistic feature (furry-ish designs attract both furries and normies, even if it's for different reasons)

He's a mix of humanoid and object Pokemon, probably two of the most disliked types of Pokemon designs. He's humanoid AND goofy. not really a combination that makes popular mons. Being good in competitive doesn't translate to actual popularity. If anything him being everywhere makes people hate him even more

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52823911
Load bearing code. Video game development works on the principle of never deleting anything from the code, because it's all so complex and interconnected that removing say, a truck, might cause a cascade of failures that crashes the game. So lots of games, especially old ones, have tons of stuff from older versions embedded in the code that you can be dug up. Like the Minus world in Super Mario Bros.

>>52823911
If I had to guess, its likely an old asset that got placed there when that section looked a little different. Of course, as development shifts and levels change, sometimes parts that were in earlier versions get forgotten about. Games with long development histories like half life 2 have all sorts of little things here and there that are the last remnants of a scrapped idea or level layout. Stalker is full of this shit, with just about every other planned feature or area getting cut either due to time constraints, technical limitations, or the devs just had a change in vision for that specific thing. There is a cut mutant lioncat enemy in the code of stalker, and all though it is no longer in the game, a taxidermied one can be found in one or two places in the game, and the sounds of a cat meowing can be heard in the ambience sometimes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52824386

What you're saying is certainly relevant to some modern games, and GameFreak are by no means the cleanest when it comes programming, but in terms of how Gen 1 work under the hood there's no possibility the truck is a piece of "load bearing code" just because of how the games work. Amending the tilesets by erasing the truck tiles or replacing them with something else wouldn't have effected anything, but it also would have been a waste of time to go in and erase it at a later stage, unless they needed more space for a different tile. Likewise, leaving the tile on the map data or replacing it with a basic floor tile wouldn't cause any issues

The likely case is, as we know it was in some of the earlier builds of the game (>>52824139) from leaks, either;

>area (Vermillion Docks) gets trimmed down over time and due to being such a minor location the programmer/map designer forgets to remove it
>isn't noticed in play-testing due to getting surf after the area is inaccessible

or

>area gets trimmed down over time and programmer/map designer thinks the sprite is cute
>leaves it in as a little inconsequential detail because amending the tileset/map was time consuming or laborious

or

>area is finished, programmer sees empty space when looking over
>decides to amend map data to have the truck, which is already present in the tileset but unused, as a small hard-to-find detail

Any are likely, especially with the knowledge that Shigeki Morimoto put Mew in just for fun right at the end of development.

Wasn't entirely sure on what rules to use for area encounters in Scarlet and Violet, but I saw that someone else used the Pokemon centers to split the Areas into smaller sections, so I went with that as well.
>Vs Katy
>Nymble
Nymble uses Struggle Bug, and Susanna strikes back with Aerial Ace. This repeats the next turn as well, with Nymble getting KO'd.
>Tarountula
Susanna hits Tarountula with Aerial Ace and gets hit with Bug Bite in return. Another Aerial Ace takes the spider out.
>Teddiursa-Tera
Susanna uses Silk Trap to slow Teddiursa down, blocking a Fury Cutter
Now faster than the bear, she hits it with Aerial Ace, and gets hit by Fury Cutter in return.
I don't want Fury Cutter to rise in power, so Silk Trap blocks the next strike.
Another Aerial Ace and Fury Cutter exchange leaves Susanna in the red, but with one final Aerial Ace, Teddiursa is defeated.

>>52717546
Starmie is really nasty, it has a +22.5% crit rate with Bubblebeam for an effective power of 65*1.5*1.8= 175bp off of 100 Special.

In RBY criticals don't do double damage, rather it's level dependent multiplier of (2*Lv+5)/(Lv+5). That means a Level 2 Rattata on Route 1 getting a critical only hits for 1.28 times damage.
I actually kind of like that, it makes the early game much less volatile, no one hit kills on an unlucky critical. And it's not like it affect competitive much since at 50 the multiplier is 1.9 and at 100 it's 1.95.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hey friends, I've been wanting to relive the days when I actually enjoyed this fucking series, so I figured I'd do a Nuzlocke challenge like the good old days. Gonna play the era I enjoy, GBA/DS. Sort of a region-travel playthrough. FireRed, SoulSilver, Emerald, Platinum, and White.

Rules aside from the normal:
>Champion Clause: Any Pokemon, living or dead, that makes it to the HoF in one game has its line stricken from all subsequent ones. This includes split evos like Eevees or Hitmons.
>Set battle style
>Wild Pokemon and Starters randomized to within the same power level to make catches actually somewhat interesting in regions with poorly-distributed Regional Dexes

Starting off with a choice of Totodile, Pichu, or Ralts with Brock as my first gym leader makes things easy, though it does unfortunately give Boomer's rival, Zoomer, what he called "an easy dub no cap fr fr" with a two-shot Thundershock. Thankfully, I don't consider the Nuzlocke to start until after Rival 1, so here we go!

>>52791319
>Giacomo
>Pawniard
I send in Sceccu, not really expecting too much trouble.
Pawniard immediately humbles me a bit, doing pretty good damage with Metal Claw, but Stamina and Iron Defense makes sure the next one won't do too much, and a Double kick in return takes out Pawniard.
>Segin Starmobile
I think the Attack of my mon dropped here, but I don't recall what caused it.
The car Snarls at Sceccu(now down to 13 HP), and takes less than impressive damage from Double Kick.
I swap in Jock McGraw on Snarl.
The car lets out a Metal Sound, and Jock hits decently hard with Force Palm.
Swift sends Jock into the red, but another Force Palm does nice damage.
I send Blue Suede in on a Swift.
The Car snarls twice at the bird as it Aerial Aces. A third would kill Blue Suede, so I send in Douce Dame on on a Snarl.
A Metal Sound drops the special defense of Douce Dame far enough that I don't want to stay in after the Take Down.
I send Greensleeves in on Snarl.
Another Metal Sound is fairly meaningless, as Seed Bomb reduces the Starmobile to more or less a single point of health, which Quick Attack takes care of.
Pretty impressed with how much work the Starmobile actually had me put in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52793062
Decided to activate the Kofu events and go to the Marinada auctions early, but I underestimated Kofu's underling Hugo, who took out Blue Suede with his Floatzel.
The fight against Iono was the last big one I did before Christmas, and boy, I completely screwed it up.
>Vs Iono
I had planned on beating her whole squad with Bulk Up Terastal Black Belt Hariyama... but somehow I forgot her first mon was
>Wattrel
Despite my mistake, I decide to double down and muscle through the bird. Jock Terastalizes as he Fakes the bird Out.
However, Air Slash does some decent damage next turn and Knock Off doesn't finish the bird off, meaning another turn of the same two moves follow, but Wattrel finally falls.
>Bellibolt
I no longer have the health or time to setup Bulk Ups, so I go directly for Force Palm. Bellibolt takes less than half, Charges up, and hits decently hard with Spark. If I don't swap Jock out, I'm losing here.
I send in Sceccu for free on Spark. Two Bulldozes deal with the frog, but not without a Water Gun crit doing nasty damage inbetween.
>Luxio
It intimidates Sceccu. A Bite does fairly insignificant damage, and two Bulldozes in a row takes out the cat.
>Lil' Lightbulb Mismagius
Sceccu almost gets reduced to red health by Hex, but gets a Strength in.
I swap in the mon I hope will be able to patch my mistakes: Ezy Rider. Hex does nothing.
Ezy Rider hits the Lightbulb with Breaking Swipe, doing really good damage. Sadly, Ezy gets hit by a Confuse Ray as well.
He hits himself, and Mismagius uses Charge Beam(SpA up!).
Another Breaking Swipe lands, putting Iono's ace into the red, but Charge Beam powers Mismagius up further.
I don't really have a safe switchin bar Sceccu(but I'm a bit frazzled at this point and his low health keeps me from picking him), so I stick with Ezy.
Sadly, he hit himself again, and the Charge Beam does just enough to down the lizard.
Douce Dame comes in to avenge him, and finishes the fight with Ice Shard.

>>52819550
Mints don't actually change the nature. It just makes the Pokémon have the effect of another nature while retaining its actual nature. So they arnt pretending to be anything. The Pokémon acts the same while getting different Stat boosts. It's perfect.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Natures are one of Game Freak's ways of making individual Pokemon unique and having its own personality, which was why they made the Battle Palace in Emerald's Battle Frontier. However, rather than having a diverse team, every single Pokemon on the player's team ended up being one of the 6-8 useful natures. So Game Freak have added mints to the game so that any Pokemon you catch in the game, they don't change the personality of the Pokemon but they allow the stats to be min-maxed.

They've also made IVs easy to change with bottle caps now, so that the characteristic of the Pokemon can be diverse. People mocked the guy who wanted a "Proud of its power" Lucario but that's the exact sort of thing that Game Freak wants people to pay attention to.

>>52823637
Correct me if this wasn't your intention, but the way you're framing it makes it sound like you think only the players who voted to take action get to vote for which action to take.
If that was the case, I'd agree this is a BS kangaroo suspect to get rid of tera, because then the votes for reasonable action would be split and outnumbered by votes to ban.
But that isn't the case. Read the rules more carefully.
Even if you vote "no action", you still get to rank your preferred choices if action does end up being taken. And because anyone who votes "no action" is overwhelmingly likely to list banning at the bottom of their preferred actions, the suspect is actually biased against a ban.

If they wanted tera gone, this is the worst possible way to go about it.

So I just picked this game up and I've been enjoying it for the most part but there's a few things I want to address. Feel free to post anything related to the new game in this thread or stop by to call me a fag.

1. Why the fuck does every building I come across feel fake and empty? There are a bunch of food shops but you don't actually go inside, it functions more like a fancy vending machine. It makes the world feel less meaningful. I'm enjoying the open world aspect but it feels like they cut some serious corners with interior design. This is the only aspect of the game I'm genuinely disappointed with so far.
2. All the gyms I've come across so far have the same design. Not a big deal but worth noting. I understand the fights are unique but I'm talking about the building design.
3. Is this region supposed to be in Mexico or some other latin country? Are sandwiches really that big of a deal in Mexico? I would have assumed the cooking element would be tacos or something.
4. What the fuck is wrong with the NPCs? There is a large influx of the following: obese fucks, gender ambiguous fucks, brown fucks, and just downright weird/ugly looking fucks. It's like someone in charge got a memo to do some checklist tier diversity but went about it like a Japanese robot. This topic isn't really a pain point because it's been amusing so far.
5. Nemona can catch this D.

Despite your instance of that it's not the case in the context of pokephilia. This is why having some data at hand is important, having voting systems in image archives and reddit can help shine light on this but smash or pass is an invaluable tool given to us because it's the first polls of it's kind with large numbers of participants. From there it's an issue of looking at other outside factors like raw numbers and reception among the general public and other sites that allow voting.

Based off this Vaporeon is very much in the conversation. Memes, while meant to be funny, often have an element of truth to them and given how widespread the vaporeon meme is, Vaporeon is unmatched here, it shows that it's a legitimate force since it's backed up by other factors. Vaporeon, has far as the data is concerned, is very much dominant in the NSFW sphere and it fares fare better than the vast majority of Pokémon. Pokémon isn't a series where conventional ideas prevail, it's unique context and reception allow it to be an interesting casestudy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52817912
In what way? Nothing suggests it's a meme, you don't see "meme" picks scoring high. The mentioned Ninetales placing and those around it indicate a deliberate picking. Verily so given how Vaporeon has entered the public consciousness in the meme sphere in places like reddit and Twitter we shouldn't act surprise when these results start to show up. As far as I know there's no mention of people manipulating the poll like the Twitter poll that ran in Japan and indeed the results pretty much reflect what you see in other sources and helps paint a clearer picture here.

I've said it before but results like this reflect the attitudes seen in the series itself. The series itself often makes no distinction between Pokémon and their place in the world so should we really act too surprised by these results? Any stigma related to shape is greatly diminished because the series itself doesn't care about shape, it cares about the construction and perception of Pokémon as cute little critters and pets. This, I believe, is what allowed Pokémon like Vaporeon to reach great memetic status that no other Pokémon has and thi manifests itself in these results, in NSFW material and reception in social media. With this data, while not perfect, is enough where a coherent picture starts to emerge. For example how demographics can hard carry, and hinder, certain Pokémon as is the case with Lykanroc and Tsareena. Tsareena, despite scoring high, lacks sexualizition so it never entered the public consciousness unlike other Pokémon because in this context perception and sexualizition is key. These ideas wouldn't have come forth without the results from smash or pass which along with other factors allow us to dispell notions and have a clearer view of the puzzle that is pokephilia.

This gives me an idea, DC characters but adapted to the pokemon world, no superpowers, they would be more attached to the franchise's NPC trainers (as far as possible), their sidekicks/minions would be replaced by pokemon, only using the most representative characters as trainers.

For example, Diana would be a 10yo buff tomboy recently arrived from an unknown region, she is adventurous and reckless, to the point of fighting together with her Aegislah pokemon.

Clark the friendly rival, a Pokemon breeder who lives on a farm (Actually he came to Unova as a baby from Ultra Space along with his Cosmog)

Bruce the edgy rival, a rich kid who constantly changes his main Pokemon, first a Riolu, then a Charcadet, followed by a Hawlucha,.....

Lex would be a gym leader with aspirations to become the champion, basing his battles on strategy over brute force.

Barb is a member of Team Rocket who only joined for her own selfish interests, her ace being a Liepard.

J is a Juggler/Clown/Harlequin trainer looking to destroy the league, just for fun, his partner is a female Meowscarade who would do anything for his trainer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Gengar:
>Lurking in the shadowy corners of rooms, it awaits chances to steal its prey's life force.
>It is said to emerge from darkness to steal the lives of those who become lost in mountains.
Washizu stole the blood of young people earning him the nickname of a 'vampire'. However, unlike the bat pokémon, Gengar doesn't suck their life force/blood to sruvive, but seems to do it out of pure malicious intent, like Washizu.

Absol:
Seen just before disasters, but gone when they happen. Reflects Washizu's ability to be in a place just before disaster like in the war due to his ability to almost predict the future and escape his death. It also has the ability Super Luck, and Washizu has been described as having a "God-like" luck, which almost even allowed him to beat Akagi at Mahjong.

Xatu:
Can see the future, and it stands still, pensive, because it is said it sees horrible things. Washizu's genius allowed him to leave the military and survive the war just before Japan was destroyed, leading to people claim he could "see the future".

Kingambit:
Washizu considers himself the secret king/emperor of Japan, and Kingambit is a chess King with an obviously very Japanese design. Additionaly, it is Dark type, and Washizu is so evil he escaped Hell after leading a revolution.

Gholdengo:
Washizu loves money. Having it and gaining more is all he cares for. Gholdengo has an ability that lets you gain 5X more money at the end of a battle.

Yveltal:
Washizu is terrified of death since he is so old, and wishes he were immortal, coping with this fear by killing young men. Yveltal steals the life of things around itself just when it is about to die, then rejuvenates, like Washizu wishes he could do.

posts.com:
>>52809002
Following the Leon battle and Project Mew conclusion, an episode preview appeared showing Chloe and Ash on a train together, and for once, Chloe seemed interested in what Ash was saying. Given the fact that she spent the entire series not giving a shit about Ash, coupled with her appearing bored during the Leon battle whereas Dawn was hyped to the moon, led to memes that she suddenly wanted Ash for herself since he was now famous and probably rich. These memes stated that Dawn had unintentionally cucked herself by making Chloe interested in Ash, and how Chloe's education made her more able to manipulate the situation to her benefit, and how she would "protect" Ash from being preyed upon by girls from his past, all while proceeding to milk him for all he was worth as a 100% gold digger. After a while, this was expanded upon by people who suddenly found bloomboltshipping unironically cute, largely due to Ash and Chloe's contrasting personalities (and the apparent "realistic" nature of the gold digger swooping in with minimal effort and stealing the nice guy that other girls had spent time trying to court), by having Chloe, in the midst of her gold-digging, slowly develop genuine feelings and then finally fall head over heels for Ash. This memeship initially caused both Pearlshippers and Amourshippers to get mad, but Dawnfags warmed to it and it's now an occasional humorous fixture of Dawn threads.

>>52822479
Given that Tinkaton has access to Mold Breaker, it could be an interesting deterrent to Gholdengo by forcefully twaving/encore/skill swapping it. Even with the infamous >75 completely uninvested, Gigaton Hammer hits exactly as hard as an Adamant Garchomp's +0 EQ in doubles (I was shocked by the math myself), so it can at least finish off neutral yellow-range targets (something many supports lack)

>0 Atk Mold Breaker Tinkaton Gigaton Hammer vs. 0 HP / 0 Def Mew: 135-160 (39.5 - 46.9%) -- guaranteed 3HKO
>252+ Atk Garchomp Earthquake vs. 0 HP / 0 Def Mew: 135-159 (39.5 - 46.6%) -- guaranteed 3HKO

94 Base Speed may not be much, but with full investment and a beneficial nature, it's enough to speed-tie neutral-nature Iron Jugulis (108 base speed). Merely being Steel/Fairy with "passable" defenses is enough to consider looking into. Here's a quick sample set I came up with:

Tinkaton @ Air Balloon
Ability: Mold Breaker
Tera Type: Steel
EVs: 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe
Jolly Nature
- Gigaton Hammer
- Thunder Wave
- Skill Swap
- Thief

More typical screen/rock/debuff-setter builds also exist too (it has a rather generous movepool), though this is one such "support" Tinkaton build.

>What is it?
https://www.pokeclicker.com/
Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>Crobat?
https://crobat4.github.io/pokeclicker/
A modified version of Pokeclicker that features QoL changes from the original, including a Dock shortcut, type-based pokeball selection, Gen 3+ berries being available in dungeons, un-nerfed experience gains, and some egg-exclusive pokemon being available through other means.

>Wiki
https://pokeclicker.miraheze.org/wiki/Home_Page

>CODES
Start Menu > Save > Enter Code
>OOOSHINY

Baffling to me an open source browser game in 2022 won't even allow discussion of modding while real games include mod suppport, encourage modding, or even integrate mods into their games as features. Beyond being silly, they're killing off the scriptDev-to-gameDev pipeline. You've got a niche group of people who know how to code, have spent time getting familiar with the game's code, and are invested enough in the game to write for it. They're low hanging fruit for recruitment, but if they drop into the Discord they'll find that even discussing scripts is enough to get you branded by a condescending mod. It's not just a few people either: the main script github repository has 238 forks and 144 stars compared to 247 forks and 391 stars on the games actual repo. That's a lot of developer investment to spit in the face of.

>>52811471
Its ideal to completely infect your whole collection.
If you were to infect enough, you should see the pokerus symbol on every route and dungeon that has pokemon you have caught and infected.
Getting to 50 evs on the right pokemon will turn that symbol blue on both the pokemon, and routes and dungeons if all the pokemon in them are resistant. Pretty much, Pokerus is Good if you keep your catching / passive catching.
Of course, There are pokemon that don't benefit from pokerus yet, due to being obtainable ONCE, or do not show up in the wild, wandering, shops, or evolution item results.
But, still worth infecting when the day comes they will be.

>>52811616
The game's FAQ from the top right corner of the screen , 3 quarters the way down the list, almost completely scrolled down in that interface says as much as you need to know about EVs.

The only thing it doesn't tell you is that the Macho Brace can only ever be equipped on a single pokemon at a time, will have to unequip it, then equip a different new one. buyable only at the Fight Area in Sinnoh post e4. For every Rowap Berry that is active in the Farm will also boost ev gains from each source, also affected by the lum berry boost, too. The multipliers stack, and you can easily get resistance if you keep the combo up.

>>52811914
Various evolved pokemon do end up in the wild in the later regions, however, if you can "repeat" the evolution process with an item, That will gain EVs. Some pokemon get new evolution methods in later generations that use items, Like Magnezone, Leafeon, Glaceon, In Galar, so there is lots of potential to gain evs later.
Certain baby pokemon, or pokemon that requires you to hatch another pokemon that don't show up in the wild will leave you REALLY out of luck. In Crown Tundra you will be able to find wild fossil pokemon, as reviving fossils won't give you evs either

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52824441
Everyone talking about the graphical stuff, but nobody really harps on the QC for the writing itself. It's pretty atrocious, even for Pokémon which is no stranger to being "wide as an ocean, shallow as a puddle." The endings of the three stories feel incongruent in that they just sort of feel tacked on. It's bad enough that the path through the game is "open world" in air quotes and that the plot points you discover are presented in really clunky ways. But none of the endings of the three stories felt satisfying, with the E4 being the most disappointing because you just kind of end up there and do it and that's it. It doesn't have that grand epic feel that it didn't older games where you knew this was the end game, even if it technically isn't in this game. It would have been nice if even though they let us do the stories in any order, you had to end them in a specific order or something like that. The E4 does not feel final enough and the battles against the other two story bosses felt almost like unrelated roadblocks to reaching what comes after the E4.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52820296
>Does anyone know what exactly triggers finding expeditions?
From what I can tell, it's mostly random. Planting flowers seems to make it more likely, but at least in the past just going to an area that I haven't lit up on the world map (no green in the lifelog/expedition map) has gotten me more stuff. Even then, planting flowers only seems to work a few times per week before things stop showing up.

Should also be noted that seedlings are significantly less likely to show up if you already have a bunch from nearby S2 cells (no idea what size they are, but the rectangle they occupy in the Pikmin map screen suggest they're based on S2 cells). Either releasing them or doing activity in places with no Pikmin collected from should increase odds of getting more seedlings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52820887
>Does releasing Pikmin do anything besides delete them?
You get 10 default petals from whatever color of nectar it was fed most recently. Very useful if you are low on nectar for a certain color or don't need any more Pikmin of a certain type for mushroom challenges.
>about how much of the map do you have discovered
Basically nothing, since that would require playing the game in every corner of the Earth. I also don't tend to leave my local area just to get more expeditions.
>how many expeditions do you get daily on average?
Ignoring detector expeditions, I usually get a couple if I'm walking around or a few (3 or more) if I plant at least 250 flowers.
>We're going hiking on Friday which is about 40 minutes away... do you ever get any expeditions from far away places like that?
You're probably more likely to get expeditions around places with many Niantic points of interest (POIs), but you'll probably still get a few things on that hike. I certainly get a good amount of expeditions from hiking spots in the middle of nowhere.

>Drawcard Template (+ some old examples)
http://imgur.com/a/LTgWW#0

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Please provide references in ONE image, especially when requesting something outside of the Pokémon universe. If you request something from the old Drawthread or a separate thread, COPY & PASTE the actual request instead of posting a link.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

posts.sub: Pokemon Scarlet and Violet Remove Long-Standing Female Empowerment Feature for No Reason
posts.com: >For the most part, Pokemon Scarlet and Violet introduce great new features or further improve on the foundations laid by others in the past, which makes Gen 9 one of the best mainline games released so far even considering performance issues. There is arguably a much higher level of attention to detail in Gen 9 than other game in the franchise, to the point that Game Freak added specific animations for how some Pokemon disappear from the overworld, for example. Character customization in Pokemon Scarlet and Violet has made significant leaps forward compared to Gen 8 alone, but it's not always a bed of roses.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>A great example is that Pokemon Scarlet and Violet players can never take their school uniform off, nor change the way it looks outside of four predetermined outfits - one for every season. As such, players' freedom is quite limited because school uniforms are such an overbearing part of the whole outfit that it's hard to make anything else pop, especially considering that their colors cannot be changed. However, this is far from the worst issue that character customization entails in Gen 9, as Pokemon Scarlet and Violet completely remove the ability to wear skirts in Paldea.

>Often considered a symbol of female empowerment, skirts and dresses have been part of Pokemon games for almost a decade now, as they were introduced with Pokemon X and Y. As such, Pokemon Scarlet and Violet removing both skirts and dresses entirely not only makes no sense, but it breaks a major tradition that had only helped the franchise grow thanks to trainers across the world being able to choose what their in-game avatars looked like. School uniforms always come with shorts and pants regardless of the character gender that players pick at the beginning of the game, which doesn't make much sense.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Pokemon Scarlet and Violet's gendered language is already a big issue within the game when Gen 9 seemingly promotes a more open approach to LGBTQIA+ representation both via its NPCs and the character customization menu, and the lack of clothing options doesn't help. Allowing players to wear skirts and dresses would have continued a 10-year trend that had no reason to be stopped in its tracks, to begin with. This makes even less sense when one considers how Pokemon Brilliant Diamond and Shining Pearl ended up including more clothing customization than Gen 9 does, accessories aside.

>Still, LGBTQIA+ representation in Pokemon Scarlet and Violet is better than it's ever been. For instance, Rika from Pokemon Scarlet and Violet's Elite Four seems to be introduced as a non-binary character, and allowing all characters to wear skirts would have taken this further. While Gen 9 also features some prominent characters wearing a dress, with them being the sisters Ryme and Tyme, as well as Poppy from the Elite Four, and Tulip from the Alfornada Gym, skirts seem to be completely absent from Paldea. Thus, even good representation and character customization features don't shine as much as they would, leaving players wondering why skirts couldn't be included, to begin with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Furthermore, if four characters in the entire game can wear a dress, making it impossible to do so for players stings even more because it's probably not a matter of character models, then. The reason why dresses were cut could be rooted in the design for school uniforms, but even then, skirts could have been made available to players anyway, which makes this point moot. As such, there is seemingly no answer to why Game Freak decided to remove a longstanding female-empowering feature that's been present since Gen 6, and it's unlikely that Pokemon Scarlet and Violet's DLC will fix this.

>>52819788
>However I disagree that people should always play with the same favorite mons. To me novelty of new games is finding out new favorites.
That is very much true, but thats not how transfers work in practice. Since generation 4, the process of transferring pokemon from one game to another have always been reserved for the end of the game. To send pokemon from ruby/sapphire/emerald to diamond/pearl/platinum, you needed to beat the elite 4 in sinnoh and obtain the national pokedex to unlock Pal Park, which made transfer possible. In gen 5, you had to beat the game and obtain the national dex afterwards to unlock poke transfer. And in gen 6 & 7 there was pokemon bank and transporter. While the last was not restricted to endgame, you wouldnt be able to use your old teams in the new games right from the start. It was never about using only old pokemon, but being able to play with them and not losing them to time. You still played the new game with the new pokemon, and when you had your fun with the new guys you'd bring over your old guys too. But now with Dexit, you either transfer up and never play with your older pokemon, or you keep them in the same game until the internal batteries run out or something happens to the original cartridge. It is incredibly disappointing that corners were cut with absolutely nothing to show for it. A sacrifice made for a worse outcome.
